title: How miscommunication happens (and how to avoid it) - Katherine Hampsten

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the transmission model of communication?

options.label: A
options.text: It views communication as a game of catch.

options.label: B
options.text: It views communication as a message that moves directly from one person to another.

options.label: C
options.text: It acknowledges the many added challenges of communicating.

options.label: D
options.text: It thinks of communication between people as a two-way street.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the complications that arises from the transactional model of communication?

options.label: A
options.text: It's a game of catch where one person always throws the ball.

options.label: B
options.text: It's a game of catch where the ball is always caught by one person.

options.label: C
options.text: It's a game of catch where the ball is shaped by the subjective lenses of each person.

options.label: D
options.text: It's a game of catch where the ball is always thrown and caught by the same person.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the practices that can help us navigate our daily interactions for better communication?

options.label: A
options.text: Recognize that communication is a one-way street.

options.label: B
options.text: Engage actively with the verbal and nonverbal feedback of others.

options.label: C
options.text: Listen with only your ears.

options.label: D
options.text: Take time to understand only as you try to be understood.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the elements that influence how you see the world according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Your personal preferences.

options.label: B
options.text: Your culture, community, and family.

options.label: C
options.text: Your age, race, and gender.

options.label: D
options.text: Your knowledge and past experience.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the last practice mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Be aware of your personal perceptual filters and elements of your experience.

options.label: B
options.text: Be aware of the other person you are communicating with and their subjective lenses.

options.label: C
options.text: Be aware of the many added challenges of communicating.

options.label: D
options.text: Be aware of the complexity of communication.

title: How to let go of being a "good" person — and become a better person - Dolly Chugh

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, why do we tend to go into "red-zone defensiveness" when our good person identity is challenged?

options.label: A
options.text: Because we are overestimating the importance of our inner compass in our ethical decisions.

options.label: B
options.text: Because we are trying to protect our good person identity and avoid mistakes.

options.label: C
options.text: Because we are not aware of our own biases and flaws.

options.label: D
options.text: Because we are not used to being challenged and it makes us uncomfortable.

multiple-choice.question: What is the premise of bounded rationality, as described by the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: The human mind has unlimited storage resources and processing power.

options.label: B
options.text: The human mind relies on shortcuts to do a lot of its work due to limited storage resources and processing power.

options.label: C
options.text: The human mind is only capable of the awareness, and not outside of it.

options.label: D
options.text: The human mind is only capable of making decisions based on conscious thought.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of bounded ethicality, as described by the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Unconscious bias in decision-making.

options.label: B
options.text: Conflicts of interest in business decisions.

options.label: C
options.text: A person's ability to make objective decisions without being influenced by external factors.

options.label: D
options.text: A person's ability to recognize and overcome their own biases.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the problem with our definition of being a "good person"?

options.label: A
options.text: It is too narrow and scientifically impossible to meet.

options.label: B
options.text: It is too broad and allows for too much variability.

options.label: C
options.text: It is too focused on external validation rather than internal growth.

options.label: D
options.text: It is too focused on achieving perfection rather than progress.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's suggestion for how to improve our behavior and become better people?

options.label: A
options.text: To try harder to be good people and avoid mistakes.

options.label: B
options.text: To focus on protecting our good person identity and avoid challenges.

options.label: C
options.text: To let go of being good people and set a higher standard of being a "good-ish person".

options.label: D
options.text: To focus on external validation and recognition rather than internal growth.

title: The dark history of werewolves - Craig Thomson

multiple-choice.question: What was Peter Stubbe accused of in the highly publicized trial of 1589 in Bedburg, Germany?

options.label: A
options.text: Murder and theft

options.label: B
options.text: Murder, assault, and cannibalism

options.label: C
options.text: Witchcraft and sorcery

options.label: D
options.text: Being a werewolf and performing horrific acts

multiple-choice.question: In early literature, werewolves were often portrayed as sympathetic figures, victims of curses who longed to return to their human form. What was the reason for this transformation in the story of Gilgamesh?

options.label: A
options.text: A curse placed by the goddess of love, Ishtar

options.label: B
options.text: A punishment from the god Zeus

options.label: C
options.text: A transformation caused by the devil's magic girdle

options.label: D
options.text: A result of a shepherd's love for the goddess of love, Ishtar

multiple-choice.question: What was the main reason for the European witch trials, which also targeted alleged werewolves like Peter Stubbe?

options.label: A
options.text: Fear of outsiders and society's early attempts to understand brutal crimes

options.label: B
options.text: Fear of magic and sorcery

options.label: C
options.text: Fear of cannibalism and murder

options.label: D
options.text: Fear of the devil's magic girdle

multiple-choice.question: What was the idea that the curse of werewolfism could be transmitted through bites and triggered by a full moon first popularized in?

options.label: A
options.text: The 1935 film "Werewolf of London"

options.label: B
options.text: The 1941 film "The Wolf Man"

options.label: C
options.text: The 1950s film "I Was a Teenage Werewolf"

options.label: D
options.text: The 1960s film "The Howling"

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the pentagram appearing on the palm of the werewolf's next victim in the 1941 film "The Wolf Man"?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a symbol of the werewolf's strength

options.label: B
options.text: It was a sign of the werewolf's curse

options.label: C
options.text: It was an allusion to the compulsory Star of David badges found in Europe during the 1930s and 1940s

options.label: D
options.text: It was a representation of the werewolf's love for the goddess of love, Ishtar

title: How (and why) to read William Faulkner - Sascha Morrell

multiple-choice.question: What was William Faulkner trying to achieve through his use of confusing narrative structures in his novels?

options.label: A
options.text: To create an easy-to-follow story for his readers

options.label: B
options.text: To explore the most mysterious parts of the human mind and investigate pressing issues of personal, racial, and regional identity

options.label: C
options.text: To make his readers feel bored and disconnected from the story

options.label: D
options.text: To simply entertain his audience with absurd and humorous characters

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the fictional county of Yoknapatawpha in Faulkner's novels?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a real county in Mississippi where Faulkner grew up

options.label: B
options.text: It is a fantastical reimagining of Lafayette County, Mississippi, where Faulkner spent most of his life

options.label: C
options.text: It is a place where Faulkner's characters go to escape their problems

options.label: D
options.text: It is a symbol of Faulkner's love for the American South

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of Faulkner's use of multiple narrative perspectives in his novels?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a single, objective truth about the story's events

options.label: B
options.text: To allow readers to understand the characters' biases and blindspots firsthand

options.label: C
options.text: To make the story more exciting and engaging

options.label: D
options.text: To confuse readers and make them feel lost

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the sentence in "Absalom, Absalom!" that runs 1,288 words long?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a example of Faulkner's poor writing skills

options.label: B
options.text: It is a demonstration of Faulkner's ability to create complex and engaging sentences

options.label: C
options.text: It is a example of Faulkner's use of evasive language to cover up the region's intolerable history

options.label: D
options.text: It is a joke that Faulkner inserted into the novel to make readers laugh

multiple-choice.question: What is the main theme that Faulkner explores in his novels?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of family and relationships

options.label: B
options.text: The unreliability of history and memory

options.label: C
options.text: The power of love and redemption

options.label: D
options.text: The impact of technology on society

title: How to manage your emotions

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the framework used by psychologists to identify where and how to intervene in the process that forms our emotions?

options.label: A
options.text: The Process Model

options.label: B
options.text: The Emotional Regulation Model

options.label: C
options.text: The Cognitive Behavioral Model

options.label: D
options.text: The Mood Management Model

multiple-choice.question: According to the Process Model, what are the four steps involved in forming our emotions?

options.label: A
options.text: Situation, appraisal, emotional response, and behavior

options.label: B
options.text: Situation, appraisal, behavior, and emotional response

options.label: C
options.text: Appraisal, situation, emotional response, and behavior

options.label: D
options.text: Emotional response, appraisal, situation, and behavior

multiple-choice.question: What is one strategy for regulating emotions in the Process Model, if you find yourself in a situation that makes you feel bad?

options.label: A
options.text: Avoiding the situation altogether

options.label: B
options.text: Modifying the situation to make it more pleasant

options.label: C
options.text: Shifting your attention to something else

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between reappraisal and tempering your emotional response, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Reappraisal is about changing your thoughts about a situation, while tempering your emotional response is about hiding your emotions.

options.label: B
options.text: Reappraisal is about hiding your emotions, while tempering your emotional response is about changing your thoughts about a situation.

options.label: C
options.text: Reappraisal is about changing your thoughts about a situation, while tempering your emotional response is about changing your emotions.

options.label: D
options.text: Reappraisal is about changing your emotions, while tempering your emotional response is about changing your thoughts about a situation.

multiple-choice.question: What is the conclusion of the transcript regarding the question of whether one should always try to be happy?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, you should always try to be happy.

options.label: B
options.text: No, you should always try to be happy.

options.label: C
options.text: It depends on the situation.

options.label: D
options.text: It depends on how you define what makes a mood "good".

options.text: 10 million

options.label: B
options.text: 86 billion

options.text: 1 million

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Dragonfly

options.label: A
options.text: 10 milliseconds

options.label: B
options.text: 50 milliseconds

options.label: C
options.text: 100 milliseconds

options.label: D
options.text: 200 milliseconds

options.label: A
options.text: To create a computer that can replicate the activity patterns of neurons

options.label: B
options.text: To understand how brains do basic calculations and build blocks for more complex functions

options.label: C
options.text: To develop a new navigation device based on dung beetles or ants

options.label: D
options.text: To create a small army of drones to defend against mosquitoes

options.label: A
options.text: 10 watts

options.label: B
options.text: 20 watts

options.label: C
options.text: 50 watts

options.label: D
options.text: 100 watts

title: The myth of Loki’s monstrous children - Iseult Gillespie

multiple-choice.question: What were the three fearsome figures that haunted Odin's dreams?

options.label: A
options.text: A massive, writhing shadow; a shambling, rotting corpse; and a monstrous beast with a deadly bite.

options.label: B
options.text: A serpent, a glowing young woman, and a small wolf.

options.label: C
options.text: A wolf, a snake, and a giant.

options.label: D
options.text: A bear, a dragon, and a giant.

multiple-choice.question: Why did Odin summon Thor and Tyr to travel to Jotunheim?

options.label: A
options.text: To capture Loki and bring him back to Asgard.

options.label: B
options.text: To capture Loki's secret children.

options.label: C
options.text: To stop Loki from visiting the giantess Angrboda.

options.label: D
options.text: To stop Loki from sneaking off to visit Angrboda.

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the wolf that Loki's children produced, and what happened to it?

options.label: A
options.text: Fenrir, it was banished to the sea at the edge of the world.

options.label: B
options.text: Fenrir, it was sent deep below the earth to join its fellow corpses.

options.label: C
options.text: Fenrir, it was bound with Gleipnir, an unbreakable chain.

options.label: D
options.text: Fenrir, it was killed by Odin.

multiple-choice.question: What happened to Tyr's wrist when Fenrir bit through it?

options.label: A
options.text: It was healed instantly.

options.label: B
options.text: It was broken but not severed.

options.label: C
options.text: It was severed, and a torrent of saliva became a furious river.

options.label: D
options.text: It was injured but not severed.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of Odin's actions in binding Fenrir?

options.label: A
options.text: He was able to stop Fenrir from growing stronger.

options.label: B
options.text: He was able to defeat Fenrir and save Asgard.

options.label: C
options.text: He sealed his own doom, as Fenrir vowed to destroy him.

options.label: D
options.text: He was able to banish Fenrir to the Underworld.

title: 3 rules for better work-life balance - Ashley Whillans

multiple-choice.question: What is the cost of constant interruptions to our personal lives, according to research?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased stress and happiness

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased stress and increased happiness

options.label: C
options.text: A tremendous loss of productivity and meaningful experiences

options.label: D
options.text: No cost at all

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of parents who were told to check their phone as much as possible during a visit to a science museum with their kids?

options.label: A
options.text: They reported that the experience was more meaningful and they felt more connected to their kids.

options.label: B
options.text: They reported that the experience was significantly less meaningful and they felt much lonelier.

options.label: C
options.text: They reported that the experience was neutral and they felt no change in feelings.

options.label: D
options.text: They didn't notice any difference.

multiple-choice.question: What is one strategy that can be taken to treat upcoming time off like a vacation?

options.label: A
options.text: To plan a expensive and extravagant trip.

options.label: B
options.text: To create clear boundaries for your time off and plan activities that bring joy.

options.label: C
options.text: To check email and work during your time off.

options.label: D
options.text: To not plan anything and just wing it.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of negotiating for more time at work?

options.label: A
options.text: It can lead to increased stress and burnout.

options.label: B
options.text: It can lead to lower levels of stress and burnout, and be seen as more committed and professional by colleagues.

options.label: C
options.text: It has no impact on stress and burnout levels.

options.label: D
options.text: It can lead to decreased productivity.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way to reframe rest and reclaim it?

options.label: A
options.text: By seeing it as an unproductive barrier to work.

options.label: B
options.text: By treating upcoming time off like a vacation and creating clear boundaries for your time off.

options.label: C
options.text: By not taking time off at all.

options.label: D
options.text: By checking email and working during your time off.

title: How can we support the emotional well-being of teachers? - Sydney Jensen

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Links statue at Lincoln High School?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It symbolizes the school's commitment to academic excellence.

options.label: C

options.text: Providing support to students with diverse and tough circumstances.

options.label: C
options.text: Meeting the demands of standardized testing and curriculum requirements.

options.label: B
options.text: Burnout and stress.

options.label: C
options.text: Depression and anxiety.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

options.label: B
options.text: By hosting wellness events and activities for teachers.

options.label: C
options.text: By increasing the number of school counselors and therapists.

options.label: D

options.text: To display student artwork.

options.label: B
options.text: To represent the school's athletic teams.

options.label: C

title: The rise and fall of the Lakota Empire - Pekka Hämäläinen

multiple-choice.question: In what year did a powerful empire born in North America, and what was its significance?

options.label: A
options.text: 1775, marking the beginning of a new era of colonialism.

options.label: B
options.text: 1776, marking the birth of a powerful empire.

options.label: C
options.text: 1804, marking the beginning of a close trade alliance between the Lakotas and the United States.

options.label: D
options.text: 1876, marking the final straw for the Lakotas.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the Lakotas' control of the Black Hills, or Paha Sapa?

options.label: A
options.text: It marked the Lakotas as the dominant power in the American East.

options.label: B
options.text: It marked the Lakotas as the dominant power in the American West.

options.label: C
options.text: It marked the beginning of the Lakotas' expansion into the eastern woodlands.

options.label: D
options.text: It marked the end of the Lakotas' buffalo hunting grounds.

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of the California gold rush on Lakota territory and buffalo herds?

options.label: A
options.text: It brought hordes of white settlers who encroached on Lakota territory and disturbed the buffalo herds.

options.label: B
options.text: It brought trade opportunities that benefited the Lakotas.

options.label: C
options.text: It led to the decline of the Lakotas' buffalo hunting skills.

options.label: D
options.text: It led to the Lakotas' expansion into the eastern woodlands.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the Battle of the Little Bighorn in 1876?

options.label: A
options.text: The Lakotas were decisively defeated by the Americans.

options.label: B
options.text: The battle was a draw, with both sides suffering heavy losses.

options.label: C
options.text: The Lakotas led by Crazy Horse decisively defeated the Americans.

options.label: D
options.text: The battle was cancelled due to bad weather.

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of the US Army's massacre of hundreds of Lakotas at Wounded Knee Creek in 1890?

options.label: A
options.text: It marked the end of the Lakotas' resistance movement.

options.label: B
options.text: It led to the Lakotas' acceptance of reservations and the dismantling of their culture.

options.label: C
options.text: It led to the Lakotas' continued fight for their culture and land.

options.label: D
options.text: It had no significant impact on the Lakotas' struggle for their culture and land.

title: Who decides what’s in the dictionary? - Ilan Stavans

options.label: B

title: Demolition, disease, and death: Building the Panama Canal - Alex Gendler

options.label: A
options.text: Ferdinand de Lesseps

options.label: B
options.text: Teddy Roosevelt

options.label: C
options.text: Woodrow Wilson

options.label: D
options.text: Charles Darwin

multiple-choice.question: What was the main reason why the French attempt to build a canal through the Isthmus of Panama failed?

options.label: A
options.text: Lack of funding

options.label: B
options.text: High number of landslides and landslides

options.label: C
options.text: Tropical diseases and poor infrastructure

options.label: D
options.text: Insufficient manpower

multiple-choice.question: What was the innovative plan used by the Americans to build the Panama Canal?

options.label: A
options.text: Cutting the mountain down to sea level

options.label: B
options.text: Building massive steel gates to separate the canal into multiple chambers

options.label: C
options.text: Raising the sea up the mountain using massive steel gates

options.label: D
options.text: Excavating the entire mountain

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the dam built across the Chagres river valley to provide a natural solution for the canal's water needs?

options.label: A
options.text: Gatun Dam

options.label: B
options.text: Culebra Dam

options.label: C
options.text: Panama Dam

options.label: D
options.text: Isthmus Dam

multiple-choice.question: How many vessels travel through the Panama Canal annually, and how long does it take for each vessel to pass through the canal?

options.label: B
options.text: 14,000 vessels in under 12 hours

options.label: C
options.text: 20,000 vessels in 48 hours

options.label: D
options.text: 30,000 vessels in 72 hours

title: How the world’s tallest skyscraper was built - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What innovation in building design allowed for the construction of the 828-meter Burj Khalifa in Dubai?

options.label: A
options.text: The use of industrial steel frames.

options.label: B
options.text: The development of tubular designs.

options.label: C
options.text: The introduction of concrete exoskeletons.

options.label: D
options.text: The creation of internal supporting columns.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the Bangladeshi-American engineer credited with developing the tubular design for skyscrapers?

options.label: A
options.text: Fazlur Khan.

options.label: B
options.text: Skidmore.

options.label: C
options.text: Owings.

options.label: D
options.text: Merrill.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the design that took Fazlur Khan's exoskeleton design one step further, with a central column supported by three protruding wings?

options.label: A
options.text: Tubular design.

options.label: B
options.text: Buttressed core.

options.label: C
options.text: Exoskeleton design.

options.label: D
options.text: Steel frame design.

multiple-choice.question: What was the main reason for the completion of the Burj Khalifa in a staggeringly short five-year period?

options.label: A
options.text: The innovative design of the building.

options.label: B
options.text: The availability of advanced construction materials.

options.label: C
options.text: The large workforce and long working hours.

options.label: D
options.text: The construction company's focus on cost-cutting measures.

multiple-choice.question: What were the working conditions like for the South Asian migrants who worked on the Burj Khalifa project?

options.label: A
options.text: They worked regular hours and were paid a fair wage.

options.label: B
options.text: They worked long hours but were paid a decent wage.

options.label: C
options.text: They worked long hours for a daily wage of roughly $10.

options.label: D
options.text: They worked short hours for a daily wage of roughly $10.

title: This tool will help improve your critical thinking - Erick Wilberding

multiple-choice.question: What was Socrates known for, rather than claiming to have all the answers?

options.label: A
options.text: Claiming to know nothing at all.

options.label: B
options.text: Asking too many questions.

options.label: C
options.text: Offering explicit advice.

options.label: D
options.text: Engaging in lengthy debates.

multiple-choice.question: What was the Socratic Method primarily used for?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide definitive answers.

options.label: B
options.text: To eliminate contradictory or circular logic.

options.label: C
options.text: To challenge students' assumptions.

options.label: D
options.text: To bully students with superior intellect.

multiple-choice.question: How did Socrates describe himself in his method of questioning?

options.label: A
options.text: As a dictator, whose inquiries suppress others' ideas.

options.label: B
options.text: As a midwife, whose inquiries assist others in giving birth to their ideas.

options.label: C
options.text: As a philosopher, whose inquiries explore unexamined assumptions.

options.label: D
options.text: As a teacher, whose inquiries clarify questions and eliminate contradictions.

multiple-choice.question: What was the Socratic Method adapted to tackle in the 19th century?

options.label: A
options.text: Abstract questions of faith.

options.label: B
options.text: Judicial reasoning in American legal education.

options.label: C
options.text: Clinical medicine in the Renaissance.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is essential for a teacher employing the Socratic Method to be effective?

options.label: A
options.text: Showing off their superior intellect.

options.label: B
options.text: Being modest, genuinely curious, and affirming of every contribution.

options.label: C
options.text: Being well-versed in their subject.

options.label: D
options.text: D: All of the above.

title: Ugly History: The Spanish Inquisition - Kayla Wolf

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary reason for the Spanish Inquisition in 1478?

options.label: A
options.text: To root out heresy in the Spanish kingdoms

options.label: B
options.text: To promote the Catholic Church's influence in the region

options.label: C
options.text: To eliminate the Jewish and Muslim populations

options.label: D
options.text: To establish a new form of government in Spain

multiple-choice.question: What was the purpose of the "Edict of Grace" during the Inquisition?

options.label: A
options.text: To punish those who confessed to heresy

options.label: B
options.text: To offer mercy to those who confessed to heresy

options.label: C
options.text: To investigate anonymous accusations

options.label: D
options.text: To gather information about suspected heretics

multiple-choice.question: What was the fate of thousands of Spanish Jews in 1492?

options.label: A
options.text: They were imprisoned for years

options.label: B
options.text: They were forced to convert to Christianity

options.label: C
options.text: They were expelled from the kingdom

options.label: D
options.text: They were killed by the Inquisition

multiple-choice.question: What was the punishment for those found guilty of heresy in public gatherings called autos de fé?

options.label: A
options.text: Imprisonment, exile, or wearing a sanbenito

options.label: B
options.text: Burning at the stake

options.label: C
options.text: Both A and B

options.label: D
options.text: Neither A nor B

multiple-choice.question: What was the estimated number of people killed during the Inquisition?

options.label: A
options.text: Over 30,000

options.label: B
options.text: Between 1,000 and 2,000

title: How does artificial intelligence learn? - Briana Brownell

multiple-choice.question: What is a common characteristic of artificial intelligence systems?

options.label: A
options.text: They are self-taught but know exactly how they're doing it.

options.label: B
options.text: They are designed by computer scientists who understand exactly how they work.

options.label: C
options.text: They are often self-taught, working off a simple set of instructions to create a unique array of rules and strategies.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not capable of learning.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the type of machine learning where the program identifies features shared by sick patients but not healthy patients, and assigns values to those features' diagnostic significance?

options.label: A
options.text: Unsupervised learning

options.label: B
options.text: Supervised learning

options.label: C
options.text: Reinforcement learning

options.label: D
options.text: Active learning

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the type of machine learning where the program uses an iterative approach to gather feedback about which medications, dosages, and treatments are most effective, and creates a unique, optimal treatment plan for each patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Unsupervised learning

options.label: B
options.text: Supervised learning

options.label: C
options.text: Reinforcement learning

options.label: D
options.text: Predictive learning

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential drawback of using artificial neural networks in machine learning?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too complex to understand.

options.label: B
options.text: They are too simple to use.

options.label: C
options.text: They are not capable of learning.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not transparent.

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential area of research in machine learning that could address the issue of AI systems making decisions without being transparent about how they arrived at those decisions?

options.label: A
options.text: Building more complex AI systems.

options.label: B
options.text: Developing more advanced algorithms for unsupervised learning.

options.label: C
options.text: Making machine learning more transparent.

options.label: D
options.text: Creating more autonomous AI systems.

title: Can loud music damage your hearing? - Heather Malyuk

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the ear when exposed to sound exceeding 120 decibels?

options.label: A
options.text: The pressure of its vibrations bends or blows out hair cells.

options.label: B
options.text: The ear's upper limits vary from person to person.

options.label: C
options.text: The ossicular chain dislocates or the eardrum bursts.

options.label: D
options.text: The sound vibrations travel through solids and liquids.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the temporary loss of hearing caused by exposure to loud sounds?

options.label: A
options.text: Permanent threshold shift

options.label: B
options.text: Temporary threshold shift

options.label: C
options.text: Noise-induced hearing loss

options.label: D
options.text: Tinnitus

multiple-choice.question: What is the recommended volume level for earbud headphone use when listening for more than 90 minutes?

options.label: A
options.text: 50% or less

options.label: B
options.text: 80% or less

options.label: C
options.text: 100% or less

options.label: D
options.text: 120% or less

multiple-choice.question: What can happen to overworked hair cells in the inner ear?

options.label: A
options.text: They generate reactive oxygen species.

options.label: B
options.text: They swell and become unable to vibrate.

options.label: C
options.text: They dislocate the ossicular chain.

options.label: D
options.text: They burst the eardrum.

multiple-choice.question: What is an essential strategy for preventing hearing loss?

options.label: A
options.text: Avoiding hazardous sounds

options.label: B
options.text: Wearing earplugs when exposed to loud sounds

options.label: C
options.text: Getting a baseline understanding of your hearing

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

title: Why do we, like, hesitate when we, um, speak? - Lorenzo García-Amaya

multiple-choice.question: What do linguists call the speech components that include "ums," "ers," and "likes" that pepper our conversations?

options.label: A
options.text: Disfluencies

options.label: B
options.text: Filled pauses

options.label: C
options.text: Discourse markers

options.label: D
options.text: Hesitation phenomena

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of filled pauses in spoken communication?

options.label: A
options.text: To signal the end of a conversation

options.label: B
options.text: To buy time for the speaker's thoughts to catch up with their speech

options.label: C
options.text: To indicate a change in topic

options.label: D
options.text: To signal the start of a new conversation

multiple-choice.question: What do discourse markers, such as "like" and "well," function as in a conversation?

options.label: A
options.text: To convey literal meaning

options.label: B
options.text: To convey something about the sentence in which they appear

options.label: C
options.text: To signal the end of a conversation

options.label: D
options.text: To signal the start of a new conversation

multiple-choice.question: According to a 2011 study, what did toddlers perform better at when a later recording asked them to identify an uncommon object?

options.label: A
options.text: When the instruction contained a silent pause

options.label: B
options.text: When the instruction contained a filled pause

options.label: C
options.text: When the instruction contained a discourse marker

options.label: D
options.text: When the instruction contained no pause at all

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of filled pauses serve in most conversations?

options.label: A
options.text: To convey a world of meaning

options.label: B
options.text: To signal the end of a conversation

options.label: C
options.text: To buy time for the speaker's thoughts to catch up with their speech

options.label: D
options.text: To signal the start of a new conversation

title: The danger of silence - Clint Smith

multiple-choice.question: What is the message that Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. conveys in his 1968 speech, which the teacher has internalized?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of speaking up against injustice.

options.label: B
options.text: The power of silence in times of conflict.

options.label: C
options.text: The need to remember the words of our enemies.

options.label: D
options.text: The significance of the silence of our friends.

multiple-choice.question: What are the four core principles that the teacher posts on the board in the classroom, which every student signs at the beginning of the year?

options.label: A
options.text: Read critically, write consciously, speak clearly, and be honest.

options.label: B
options.text: Read critically, write consciously, speak clearly, and tell your truth.

options.label: C
options.text: Read critically, write consciously, speak clearly, and be silent.

options.label: D
options.text: Read critically, write consciously, speak clearly, and give up something.

multiple-choice.question: What did the teacher give up one year during Lent, and why?

options.label: A
options.text: Speaking, because it was the most valuable thing they could sacrifice.

options.label: B
options.text: Speaking, because they had given it up a long time ago.

options.label: C
options.text: Speaking, because they were trying to prove their sanctity to God.

options.label: D
options.text: Speaking, because they were afraid of what others might think.

multiple-choice.question: What is the consequence of silence, according to the teacher?

options.label: A
options.text: Silence is the absence of fear.

options.label: B
options.text: Silence is the residue of fear.

options.label: C
options.text: Silence is the sound of confidence.

options.label: D
options.text: Silence is the absence of pain.

multiple-choice.question: What is the teacher's decision for the new year, instead of giving something up?

options.label: A
options.text: To live every day as if there were a microphone tucked under their tongue.

options.label: B
options.text: To live every day as if there were a stage on the underside of their inhibition.

options.label: C
options.text: To give up speaking again.

options.label: D
options.text: To be silent and observe.

title: How to build (and rebuild) trust - Frances Frei

multiple-choice.question: What is the foundation for everything we do, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Trust

options.label: B
options.text: Empathy

options.label: C
options.text: Logic

options.label: D
options.text: Authenticity

multiple-choice.question: What is the most common wobble in the component parts of trust?

options.label: A
options.text: Authenticity

options.label: B
options.text: Logic

options.label: C
options.text: Empathy

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is a super effective, super quick fix for the empathy wobble?

options.label: A
options.text: Technology, on and away

options.label: B
options.text: Technology, off and away

options.label: C
options.text: Executive education, focusing on logic and strategy

options.label: D
options.text: A massive influx of employees

multiple-choice.question: What is the prescription for overcoming the authenticity wobble?

options.label: A
options.text: Be like everyone else

options.label: B
options.text: Be you, and celebrate your differences

options.label: C
options.text: Wear whatever makes you feel ordinary

options.label: D
options.text: Pay attention to what people want to hear from you

multiple-choice.question: What is the obligation of leaders in the room, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: To set the conditions that make it safe for people to be authentic

options.label: B
options.text: To set the conditions that make it safe for people to be quiet

options.label: C
options.text: To set the conditions that make it safe for people to be angry

options.label: D
options.text: To set the conditions that make it safe for people to be sad

title: Why bats don't get sick - Arinjay Banerjee

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the bat's immune response compared to other mammals?

options.label: A
options.text: It has a high inflammatory response

options.label: B
options.text: It has a very low inflammatory response

options.label: C
options.text: It has no response to viral infections

options.label: D
options.text: It has a response similar to other mammals

multiple-choice.question: What is the likely reason for the bat's ability to coexist with deadly viruses?

options.label: A
options.text: Its high metabolic rate allows it to fight off infections

options.label: B
options.text: Its ability to produce Reactive Oxygen Species helps to kill viruses

options.label: C
options.text: Its low inflammatory response allows it to avoid damaging its own tissues

options.label: D
options.text: Its ability to fly quickly helps it to escape from infections

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the bat's low inflammatory response?

options.label: A
options.text: It leads to a rapid increase in white blood cells

options.label: B
options.text: It leads to a controlled low-level inflammatory response

options.label: C
options.text: It leads to a complete shutdown of the immune system

options.label: D
options.text: It leads to a decrease in the bat's lifespan

multiple-choice.question: According to a 2013 study, what is unique about bat telomeres compared to other mammals?

options.label: A
options.text: They shorten more quickly

options.label: B
options.text: They shorten at the same rate

options.label: C
options.text: They shorten more slowly

options.label: D
options.text: They do not shorten at all

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential benefit of preserving bat populations?

options.label: A
options.text: It will allow humans to understand how to infect bats with viruses

options.label: B
options.text: It will allow humans to understand how to protect themselves from bat-borne diseases

options.label: C
options.text: It will allow humans to better understand the bat's unique antiviral defense systems

options.label: D
options.text: It will allow humans to understand how to use bats as a source of food

title: The Japanese myth of the trickster raccoon - Iseult Gillespie

multiple-choice.question: What was the reason for the travelling salesman's initial difficulty in selling his wares?

options.label: A
options.text: The villagers were not interested in his products.

options.label: B
options.text: He had recently traversed the region and most of the villagers had already seen his supply.

options.label: C
options.text: He was not a skilled salesman.

options.label: D
options.text: The villagers were too poor to afford his products.

multiple-choice.question: What did the salesman find at the edge of the forest that led to a new opportunity?

options.label: A
options.text: A lost child

options.label: B
options.text: A trapped tanuki

options.label: C
options.text: A rare plant

options.label: D
options.text: A buried treasure

multiple-choice.question: Why did the monks feel cheated by their purchase of the tea kettle?

options.label: A
options.text: It was too expensive.

options.label: B
options.text: It cooled too quickly.

options.label: C
options.text: It was made of low-quality material.

options.label: D
options.text: It was not what they expected.

multiple-choice.question: What transformation did the tea kettle undergo, and what was the reason for it?

options.label: A
options.text: It turned into a cat because it was hungry.

options.label: B
options.text: It turned into a tanuki because it was hot.

options.label: C
options.text: It turned into a bird because it was bored.

options.label: D
options.text: It turned into a snake because it was angry.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the salesman's encounter with the tanuki, and what did it lead to?

options.label: A
options.text: The salesman was punished for freeing the tanuki.

options.label: B
options.text: The salesman and the tanuki became enemies.

options.label: C
options.text: The tanuki became an esteemed guest of the temple.

options.label: D
options.text: The salesman lost his business.
